Biology module *Network Analysis in Ecology and Beyong* offered by [Prof. Dr. Jochen Fr√ºnd](https://jochenfruend.wordpress.com) at [University of Hamburg](https://www.biologie.uni-hamburg.de/en.html). A digital version of the poster for final presentation is available [here](). ::: ::: {.callout-caution appearance="minimal" style="font-sze:0.9rem; border-left: none; border: 1px solid var(--clcolor);" collapse="true"} ## [R Setup]{.cl-sub} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(tidyverse) library(bipartite) library(igraph) ``` ::: :::
## Mediterranean Microbiome ## Miscellaneous I worked with *Wolbachia* in my bachelor thesis - everyone who knows them should be aware of their incredible evolution. I searched for *Wolbachia* out of curious in the dataset, and found an entry in [`Prok_taxadata.txt`](https://github.com/InaMariaDeutschmann/GlobalNetworkMalaspinaHotmix/blob/main/00_Tables/Prok_taxdata.txt). No comments on this since there's no entry in quality-controlled ASV dataset. But after I read the paper [@parvathi2020] that found *Wolbachia sp* being most abundant in deep-sea sediment microbial community, I would literally not be surprised anymore if people found *Wolbachia* being most dominant in the aerosol as next. They are so ABUNDANT and they are EVERYWHERE. By the way, our *Wolbachia* - *Altica lythri* project is aiming for another publication in the proximate future. Stay tuned. See @rohlfing2024 for the latest publication.
